subject: Re: [junit] Unit 4.0 release candidate 2 Test ordering
msgSnippet: ... I would argue that you are still wasting time since the report gives you 100 tests to choose from, which is a bit silly since it knows *exactly* which one
messageBody:
On 1/20/06, Elliotte Harold <elharo@...> wrote:
>
> Cédric Beust ♔ wrote:
>
> > A typical example is Web tests: what's the point of running a hundred
> tests
> > exercising servlets if the Web server failed to start? It also helps
> for
> > the diagnostic: instead of telling the user "101 tests failed", you can
> > tell them "1 test failed, 100 tests were skipped".
> >
>
> I disagree. I occasionally do something stupid like that that breaks all
> or nearly all of my tests. Seeing that 90%+ of the tests are failing is
> a *huge* clue as to exactly what's going wrong. It keeps me from wasting
> time looking for small bugs in one class as I might do if only the first
> test failed.


I would argue that you are still wasting time since the report gives you 100
tests to choose from, which is a bit silly since it knows *exactly* which
one failed and *exactly* which ones were skipped.

Why would you prefer to read "101 tests failed" over "1 test failed, 100
tests skipped"?

--
Cédric
